vmassol - (10:19): the reason is simple: we can't guarantee the quality and maintenance and there are too few contributors

vmassol - (11:00): so that's the incentive

vmassol - (11:01): and make them be known

vmassol - (11:02): (manual process right now)

vmassol - (11:03): if I don't want it to be visible  
vmassol - (11:04): so I'll choose the best place so that it's visible to all

CalebJamesDeLisl - (11:06): But they will have no problem finding it because that's about all you get googling xwiki dynamic custom mapping.

vmassol - (11:06): (thus aggregating the world)

vmassol - (11:07): and that's the pb with your doc  
vmassol - (11:07): it's not integrated in the main doc  
vmassol - (11:07): meaning it's out of context

vmassol - (11:08): the hard part in writing docs is not writing the content  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (11:08): Some people think their work is the best thing since sliced bread, others feel that someone else needs to validate it.  
vmassol - (11:08): it's about integrating it in an existing flow  
vmassol - (11:08): so that it makes sense in that flow  
vmassol - (11:08): coherent  
vmassol - (11:08): it's like patches  
vmassol - (11:08): people who send patches do 1% of the work  
vmassol - (11:09): there's 99% left in general  
vmassol - (11:09): review, fix bugs, write tests, write docs, redesign, etc  
vmassol - (11:09): it's the same for docs  
vmassol - (11:09): it's easy to write something out of context

vmassol - (11:09): but to make it good quality, integrated, easy to read, etc is hard  
vmassol - (11:09): and takes time

vmassol - (11:10): I personally spend several hours per week on xwiki.org

vmassol - (11:11): and power users

anamarias - (11:27): When happens if doc2 is currently being edited by another user?  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (11:27): If the button posts to the save action, the document is modified anyway.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (11:28): Then when the other user saves it's reverted.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (11:28): (AFAIK)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (11:29): Locks only work if one explicitly checks to see if the document is locked.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (11:29): $doc.getLocked() I think.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (11:30): Behavior is same for Document.save() locks are ignored.  
anamarias - (11:30): I didn't know about doc.getLocked, sounds useful  
lucaa - (11:30): and when a user has started editing it, it should be locked. So when doc1 wants to save doc2, you can check for locks first to see if noone is currently editing it  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (11:31): getLocked() and getLockingUser() is another one if I remember correctly...

lucaa - (11:32): like X has opened a page in edit mode, Y wants to open it too in edit mode  
lucaa - (11:32): you get a message

lucaa - (11:33): saying that document is locked by X and if you want you can "force the lock"  
anamarias - (11:33): oh that one yes, I was referring more to custom features build on xwiki  
lucaa - (11:34): anamarias: well they should all be careful about these situations  
lucaa - (11:34): (which makes me think, I should really make a test on annotations :) )  
lucaa - (11:35): however, to check if the save is overriding the whole document or only the part modified  
lucaa - (11:35): namely, if Y saves and closes and then X saves and closes  
lucaa - (11:36): the modifications of Y would be lost, because X has overridden them with his own version that he was editing  
lucaa - (11:37): to check if this save (Ys save) affects the objects in the document or only the document content that X and Y have submitted to the save form
